lines.text: [about her doll]
Poor Margeretha, I've never seen her look so pale.
The sun oughta do her some good.
I suspect she won't live through the night, she has four fatal diseases.
And it only takes one.
But she's going to have a beautiful funeral, in a cigar box my Papa gave me, all wrapped up in silver paper.
That's the way to go, if you have to go.
Oh, she has to go.
I'm going to let John Truett kiss me tonight.
Esther Smith.
Well, if we're going to get married, I may as well start it.
Nice girls don't let men kiss them until after they're engaged. Men don't want the bloom rubbed off.
Personally, I think I have too much bloom. Maybe that's the trouble with me.
[about the pronunciation of "St. Louis"]
Well, I got a cousin who spells it the same way, and we call him "Louie".
He's isn't a city though, is he?
No...
Is he a saint?
Uh, no.
Then there's no comparison.
Sure, don't mind what happens to your family. At a time like this you think about the chickens.
Katie, where's my cat?
I don't know... a little while ago, she got in my way and I kicked her down the cellar steps. I could hear her spine hitting on every step.
Oh, if you killed her, I'll kill you! I'll stab you to death in your sleep, then I'll tie your body to two wild horses until you're pulled apart.
Oh, won't that be terrible, now? There's your cat.
Money. I hate, loathe, despise and abominate money.
You also spend it.
Oh, Katie, they were just little white lies.
A lie's a lie. Dressin' it in white don't help it. And just why was I lying this time? Why must we have dinner an hour early?
Because Rose is expecting...
Now don't go blaming your sister.
Blaming her? Why, we're doing this for her. You know Rose's problem. Warren Sheffield has been writing to her for six months without one word that even smells like a proposal.
What's that got to do with having dinner an hour early?
Warren is telephoning Rose long-distance from New York at half-past six.
Long-distance?

Yes, and if the whole family is sitting here drinking in every word, she may be loathe to say the things a girl's compelled to say to get a proposal out of a man. If that man, unfortunately, is Warren Sheffield.
Personally, I wouldn't marry a man who proposed to me over an invention.
Well, we can't be too particular. While we love Rose, the brutal fact is that, well, she isn't getting any younger.
There's the poor old maid now!
I can't get hungry till it gets dark.
Dinner's at five-thirty. You can eat blind-folded!
We have to be out of the dining room by six-thirty. Warren Sheffield is telephoning Rose from New York. And Rose, if I were you, I wouldn't committ myself one way or another. After all...
Mama, for goodness sakes!
After all, we know very little about him. Why, we haven't even met his folks.
It seems to me that one little phone call is causing an awful lot of excitement in this family!
Besides, you're entirely too young and I don't think your father will allow it.
Mrs. Smith, if I'm going to keep lying to your daughters, I'll have to ask for more money.
Now, remember, not a word of this to your papa. You know how he plagues the girls about their beaus.
Everybody knows but Papa?
Your papa's not supposed to know. It's enough we're letting him work hard every day to support the whole flock of us. He can't have everything.
[When the family finds out that they are moving to New York City permanently]
It'll take me at least a week to dig up all my dolls in the cemetery.
You'll all be safe with me; I've got twelve guns in my room!
Papa, if losing a case depresses you so, why don't you quit practicing law and go into another line of business?
That's a good idea. Starting tomorrow, I intend to play first base for the Baltimore Orioles. I'm sorry, Anna, if I was a little bombastic.
That's all right, dear, you'll feel better once you've had your dinner.
I suppose so, but right now I'm going to soak in that cool bathtub for one solid hour.
But that's impossible. Dinner's being served in five minutes.
It's only five twenty-five, not six twenty-five.
We've planned on eating an hour early tonight.
Well, the plans have just been changed. I'm taking a bath.
We're eating early for Katie's sake. Family trouble. She wants to go over there as soon as we've finished eating. Her sister's fighting with her husband.
I see. And I suppose they'll stop fighting if I don't take a bath?
Now she's been with us for ten years, and she never asks favors. We don't want to risk losing her.
No, nowadays you can't get a maid for less than twelve dollars a month.
I don't care if we have to pay a maid fifteen dollars a month! Dinner's at six-thirty, and if Katie wants to hand in her notice, she can reach me in the bathtub!
Ah, corn beef and cabbage. Katie, I could smell that cabbage when I got off the trolley.
Cabbage has a cabbage smell.
Here comes the invalid. I have to have two kinds of ice cream. I'm recuperating.
If I ever catch you fibbing again like you did about John Truett, I'll give you something to recuperate about.

[singing]
Have yourself a merry little Christmas, let your heart be light. / Next year all our troubles will be out of sight. / Have yourself a merry little Christmas, make the yule time gay / Next year all our troubles will be miles away. / Once again as in olden days, happy golden days of yore / Faithful friends who are dear to us, will be near to us once more. / Someday soon we all will be together, if the fates allow / Until then we'll have to muddle through somehow. / So have yourself a merry little Christmas now.
Agnes Smith, you're nothing less than a murderer. You could have killed dozens of people!
Oh, Rose, you're so stuck up.
Rose, what did you get me for Christmas?
You'll find out tomorrow.
I hope it's a hunting knife!
Wow, that's nice perfume.
Do you like it? It's Essence of Violet. I only take it out on special occasions
Exactly the kind my grandmother wears.
I wanna sleep right here.
Of course you will, darling.
And I wanna wear Esther's nightgown.
I'll get it for you right now.
I hate to think about what your papa's going to do when he hears about all this. He may strike that Truett boy.
I'll do that, Mama.
All right. And I'll get you some ice cream and cake, Tootie.

[singing]
Feed a cold, starve a fever. I was drunk last night, dear Mother, I was drunk the night before. But if you'll forgive me, Mother, I'll never get drunk anymore!
I got him! He didn't even have a chance to scratch me.
Why, your dress is torn.
Oh, that must've happened while he was trying to hold me off. I bit him!

[clapping her hands]
I bit him, too!
Meeting him across the lawn for the first time would be so ordinary. I don't want to be just introduced to him. I want it to be something strange and romantic and something I'll always remember.
Rose, Esther, the water's hot. We're eating early tonight, so if you're going to wash your hair, you better do it now.
All right, Mama. Es, why are we eating early?
Well, you certainly don't want the whole family sitting there drinking in every word while a man proposes to you long-distance.
Proposes? I don't see why you think Warren's going to propose to me.
Well, why else would he be calling you long-distance? Do you know what it costs?
I'm not even sure I'll be in. My dear, when you get to be my age, you'll find there are more important things in life than boys!

[singing]
Meet me in St. Louie, Louie, meet me at...
For heaven's sake, stop that screeching!
We're sorry, Papa.
The fair won't open for seven months, and that's all anybody ever sings about or talks about. I wish they would all meet at the fair and leave me alone.
Rose, it's six-thirty and Warren hasn't called yet.
Maybe he found another girl.
Quiet, you two.
Mama, I assure you that I'm not the slightest bit sensitive about Warren Sheffield.
The queen has spoken.
I suppose Warren's too young, too. Every fellow I introduce her to is too young.
Now, listen. Your papa will be down in a minute, and if we all eat quickly, we may still get out of here before the call comes through.
Warren is twenty-one and I think that's a perfect age.
He's practically a child.
Your father was twenty when we were married.
We gave him the bachelor dinner the night before. He almost missed the wedding!
Hello, Papa, I buried Maude Rockefeller today, and you missed all the fun.
Oh, I wouldn't say that. I've had a pretty full day. Tootie, remind me to spank you right after dinner.
Yes, Papa.
Lord, we thank thee for the bountiful blessing we are about to receive. Amen.
Agnes, if I forget to remind Papa, you remind me.
All right.
What did you say, Warren?
Nothing. I was waiting for you to talk.
Oh. Well, did you want to discuss anything in particular?
What?
I said, was there anything special you wanted to ask me?
I can't hear you, Rose.
That's funny. I can hear you plainly.
Isn't this great? Here I am in New York and there you are in St. Louis and it's just like you're in the next room.
What was that?
I said, it's just like you're in the next room! Uh, Rose, I hope you don't misunderstand what I'm about to say.
Yes?
I don't think you better mention this call to anyone.
We'll fix him fine. It'll serve him right for poisoning cats... He buys meat and then he buys poison and then he puts them all together.
And then he burns the cats at midnight in his furnace. You could smell the smoke...
...and Mr. Braukoff was beating his wife with a red hot poker... and Mr. Braukoff has empty whiskey bottles in his cellar.

John Truett. I've come here to ask you something... What do you mean hitting a five-year-old child?... The next time you want to hit somebody, pick on somebody your own size. If there's anything I hate, loathe, despise, and abominate, it's a bully.
[punches and kicks him]
[John Truett & Esther shakes hands]
You've got a mighty strong grip for a girl.
[after John & Esther kiss]
You've got a mighty strong grip for a boy.
It's our last dance in St. Louis. I feel like I'm going to cry.
[after John tells Esther he couldn't pick up his tuxedo from the tailor because he was busy playing basketball]
This is a fine going away present I'm giving you for Christmas. I'll bet you really hate me.
Oh, no, John, I don't hate you! I just hate basketball!
[after hearing Mr. Smith fall down the stairs]
Now I remember where I left my other skate!
[talking on the telephone]
Isn't this great? Here I am in New York, and there you are in St. Louis, and it's just like you're in the next room!
What was that?

[yelling]
I said, IT'S JUST LIKE YOU'RE IN THE NEXT ROOM!
Oh.

[on the telephone with Rose]
Wait, Rose! We still have... 36 more seconds!
I have an engagement. I think I can hear Joe's voice, now.

[lifts the tablecloth and looks under the table]
Good evening, Joe!
Tootie, if you don't hit Mr. Braukoff in the face with flour and say "I hate you", the Banshee will haunt you forever!

[moaning]
Ohhhhhhh.
What was that?
Here are your sacks of flour.
[Hand them to Tootie and Agnes]
You couldn't get me out on a night like this for a million dollars!
Did anyone here a noise just now?
Did it sound like this?
[moans again]
Ohhhhhh?
Uh-huh.

[Shakes his head]
I didn't hear it.
If you wet the flour before you throw it, it makes it harder for the victim to remove it.
[last lines]
I can't believe it. Right here where we live - right here in St. Louis.
Mrs. Smith, who are these boys?
It's me, Katie, it's Agnes!
Saints preserve us, it is! You had me fooled!
Mama, we fooled her!
Well, if you can fool our Katie, you can fool anyone.
Agnes, I thought you were a drunken ghost.
But I am. Tootie's a horrible ghost, and I'm a terrible drunken ghost.
She was murdered in a den of thieves, and I died of a broken heart. I've never even been buried because everyone's scared to come near me.
Thank you for dropping me off, Colonel Darly.
It's my pleasure, Miss Smith.
I'm sure the ice cream would have melted if it weren't for your thoughtfulness.
Glad to be of service. Good night.
Wouldn't you like to come in? There's plenty of ice cream, and I'm sure my folks would love to meet you.
Thank you, Miss Smith, but some other time.
That doctor must be walking!
Should I call Papa at his office?
Oh, heavens no, don't call your father! What could he do? There, there, Tootie, darling.
He tried to kill me...
Now tell Mommy what happened.
It was the streetcar. I think it hit her.
It must have knocked her onto the sidewalk, didn't it, Tootie?
No, it wasn't a streetcar. It was John Truett. He tried to kill me.
John Truett hit you?
He tried to kill me, and when I screamed, he ran away.
Tootie Smith, that's a monstrous falsehood. John Truett would never hit a girl, least of all my sister.
And I'm taking all my dolls, even the dead ones. I'm taking everything.
Of course you are. I'll help you pack them myself. You won't have to leave anything behind. Except your snow people, of course. We'd look pretty silly trying to get them on the train, wouldn't we?
Nobody's going to have them, not if we can't take them to New York! I'd rather kill them if we can't take them with us!
Oh, Tootie, don't cry. Don't cry, it's all right. You can build other snow people in New York.
No, you can't! You can't do any of the things that I can do in St. Louis!

No, no, Tootie, you're wrong. New York is a wonderful town. Everybody dreams about going there, but we're luckier than lots of families because we're really going. Wait till you see the nice new home we're going to have, and the loads and loads of new friends we're going to make. But the main thing is, Tootie, that we're all going to be together, just like we've always been. That's what really counts. We could be happy anywhere as long as we're together.

Rose Smith, we can't go on like this any longer. I've positively decided we're going to get married at the earliest opportunity and I don't want to hear any arguments. That's final. I love you. Merry Christmas.
Merry Christmas
Anna, who is that boy?
Now Lonny he's a very fine young man. We'll talk about it later.
That young man is so excited he's liable to leave on his honeymoon without Rose.
Excuse me, young man, but in the great country of China, when a stranger admires one of your possessions, it's common courtesy to offer it to him.
That's very interesting...
Well I spent many years in China, and if you want me to feel thoroughly at home, you might offer me your partner.
Huh?
Spoken like a true gentleman.
Gosh, Miss Esther, I hope I'm not too presumptuous, but you don't need any beauty sleep.
What a nice compliment.
Would it start a minor revolution in this household if dinner was served an hour early today?
Mr. Smith hates to eat early on a hot day.
Eating early on a hot day gives you more time to digest your food before retiring. Besides, I'm due at my sister's at seven o'clock on a family matter.
Is there something wrong with your sister?
She's having trouble with her husband. Him bein' a man.
Well, eating early is all right with me, but you'll have to explain it to Mr. Smith.
Oh, he won't mind, seein' as how tonight's corn beef night.
Anna, I'm curious, just when was I voted out of this family?
Anybody want dessert?
Dessert? What happened to dinner?
I didn't think anybody could eat meat on a hot day like this!
Oh, Es, isn't he simply enchanting? And so mature!
Well, how did it happen? Where did you meet?
I was coming out of the shop and he was coming in. We bumped into each other!
Accidentally?
Almost!
Either I've lost some soup, or I've found a spoon.

[Giggles]
Roses are red, John's name is Truett, Esther's in love, We always knew it!
Truett... Knew it... That's good. But I can't think of anything that rhymes with "Colonel" if it isn't "Infernal".
